## Core Principles

### Architectural Principles

All code must adhere to these foundational principles:

1. **Local-First Architecture**
   - IndexedDB as primary storage
   - Convex as optional cloud sync
   - Core features must work offline

2. **Progressive Enhancement**
   - Core features work without Chrome AI APIs
   - Graceful degradation for unsupported features
   - Feature detection over browser detection

3. **Component Modularity**
   - React components with clear separation of concerns
   - Single Responsibility Principle
   - Composable and reusable components

4. **Type Safety**
   - TypeScript strict mode for ALL code
   - No `any` types without explicit justification
   - Explicit return types for public APIs

5. **Performance-Driven**
   - Virtual scrolling for large lists
   - Lazy loading for routes and components
   - Code splitting at route boundaries

6. **Accessibility-First**
   - WCAG 2.1 AA compliance from the start
   - Semantic HTML
   - ARIA attributes where appropriate

## TypeScript Standards

### Configuration

**tsconfig.json must include:**
```json
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "strict": true,
    "noImplicitAny": true,
    "strictNullChecks": true,
    "strictFunctionTypes": true,
    "noUnusedLocals": true,
    "noUnusedParameters": true,
    "noImplicitReturns": true,
    "noFallthroughCasesInSwitch": true
  }
}
```

### Type Safety Rules

**DO:**
```typescript
// Explicit interfaces
interface Chat {
  id: string;
  question: string;
  answer: string;
  timestamp: Date;
}

// Explicit return types for public APIs
function saveChat(chat: Omit<Chat, 'id'>): Promise<Chat> {
  // ...
}

// Type guards
function isChat(obj: unknown): obj is Chat {
  return (
    typeof obj === 'object' &&
    obj !== null &&
    'id' in obj &&
    'question' in obj
  );
}

// Discriminated unions for state
type SyncStatus =
  | { status: 'idle' }
  | { status: 'syncing'; progress: number }
  | { status: 'synced'; timestamp: Date }
  | { status: 'error'; message: string };
```

**DON'T:**
```typescript
// ‚ùå Implicit any
function processData(data) {
  return data.map(item => item.value);
}

// ‚ùå Type assertions without validation
const chat = data as Chat;

// ‚ùå Non-null assertions without checks
const value = maybeValue!;

// ‚ùå Using 'any' without justification
const result: any = fetchData();
```

### When to Use `any`

Only use `any` with explicit comment justification:

```typescript
// JUSTIFICATION: Third-party library without types
// eslint-disable-next-line @typescript-eslint/no-explicit-any
const legacy: any = require('legacy-lib');
```

## React & Component Standards

### Component Design Patterns

#### 1. Smart vs. Dumb Components

**Smart Components (Container):**
- Manage state using Zustand hooks
- Handle data fetching (IndexedDB, Convex)
- Contain business logic
- Located in `/src/components/tabs/` or feature folders

```typescript
// Smart Component Example
export function HistoryTab() {
  const { chats, loadMore, searchQuery } = useChatStore();
  const [isLoading, setIsLoading] = useState(false);

  useEffect(() => {
    loadMore();
  }, [loadMore]);

  return (
    <div>
      <SearchInput value={searchQuery} onChange={setSearchQuery} />
      <ChatList chats={chats} isLoading={isLoading} />
    </div>
  );
}
```

**Dumb Components (Presentational):**
- Receive data via props
- No state management (except local UI state)
- Reusable across features
- Located in `/src/components/ui/`

```typescript
// Dumb Component Example
interface ChatListProps {
  chats: Chat[];
  isLoading: boolean;
  onChatClick?: (chatId: string) => void;
}

export function ChatList({ chats, isLoading, onChatClick }: ChatListProps) {
  if (isLoading) return <LoadingSpinner />;

  return (
    <ul>
      {chats.map(chat => (
        <ChatItem
          key={chat.id}
          chat={chat}
          onClick={onChatClick}
        />
      ))}
    </ul>
  );
}
```

#### 2. Compound Components

Use for components with related sub-components:

```tsx
// Compound Component Pattern
<FolderTree>
  <FolderTree.Folder name="PhD Research" count={12}>
    <FolderTree.Folder name="Literature Review" count={5} />
    <FolderTree.Folder name="Methodology" count={7} />
  </FolderTree.Folder>
</FolderTree>
```

Implementation:
```typescript
interface FolderTreeProps {
  children: React.ReactNode;
}

export function FolderTree({ children }: FolderTreeProps) {
  return <div className="folder-tree">{children}</div>;
}

interface FolderProps {
  name: string;
  count: number;
  children?: React.ReactNode;
}

FolderTree.Folder = function Folder({ name, count, children }: FolderProps) {
  const [isOpen, setIsOpen] = useState(false);

  return (
    <div>
      <button onClick={() => setIsOpen(!isOpen)}>
        {name} ({count})
      </button>
      {isOpen && children}
    </div>
  );
};
```

#### 3. Render Props for Virtualization

```tsx
<VirtualList
  itemCount={1000}
  itemSize={72}
  renderItem={({ index, style }) => (
    <ChatItem chat={chats[index]} style={style} />
  )}
/>
```

### Hooks Standards

**Custom Hook Rules:**
1. Always prefix with `use`
2. Extract reusable logic
3. Return objects, not arrays (for clarity)

```typescript
// Good: Named returns
function useChatHistory() {
  const [chats, setChats] = useState<Chat[]>([]);
  const [isLoading, setIsLoading] = useState(false);

  return { chats, isLoading, setChats };
}

// Usage
const { chats, isLoading } = useChatHistory();
```

**Effect Dependencies:**
Always include ALL dependencies or use ESLint disable with justification:

```typescript
useEffect(() => {
  fetchData(userId);
  // eslint-disable-next-line react-hooks/exhaustive-deps
  // JUSTIFICATION: Only run on mount
}, []);
```

## State Management Standards

### Zustand Store Structure

**Store Organization:**
```typescript
import { create } from 'zustand';

interface ChatStore {
  // State
  chats: Chat[];
  selectedChatId: string | null;
  isLoading: boolean;

  // Actions (grouped by feature)
  // CRUD Operations
  addChat: (chat: Omit<Chat, 'id'>) => Promise<void>;
  updateChat: (id: string, updates: Partial<Chat>) => Promise<void>;
  deleteChat: (id: string) => Promise<void>;

  // Query Operations
  searchChats: (query: string) => Promise<void>;
  filterByFolder: (folderId: string) => void;

  // Selection
  selectChat: (id: string) => void;
  clearSelection: () => void;
}

export const useChatStore = create<ChatStore>((set, get) => ({
  // Initial State
  chats: [],
  selectedChatId: null,
  isLoading: false,

  // Actions
  addChat: async (chat) => {
    set({ isLoading: true });
    try {
      const newChat = await chatService.saveChat(chat);
      set(state => ({
        chats: [newChat, ...state.chats],
        isLoading: false
      }));
    } catch (error) {
      set({ isLoading: false });
      throw error;
    }
  },

  // ... other actions
}));
```

**Store Naming Convention:**
- File: `use[Feature]Store.ts`
- Hook: `use[Feature]Store`
- Example: `useChatStore.ts` exports `useChatStore`

**Store Selectors:**
```typescript
// Use selectors to prevent unnecessary re-renders
function ChatList() {
  // ‚ùå Bad: Re-renders on ANY store change
  const store = useChatStore();

  // ‚úÖ Good: Re-renders only when chats change
  const chats = useChatStore(state => state.chats);
  const addChat = useChatStore(state => state.addChat);
}
```

## Code Organization

### File Structure

```
src/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ components/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ sidebar/          # Layout components
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tabs/             # Smart tab components
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ modals/           # Dialog components
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ui/               # Dumb presentational components
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ lib/                  # Core libraries
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ stores/               # Zustand stores
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ services/             # Business logic layer
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ types/                # TypeScript types
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ utils/                # Utility functions
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ entrypoints/          # WXT entry points
```

### Import Order

```typescript
// 1. External dependencies
import React, { useState, useEffect } from 'react';
import { useQuery } from 'convex/react';

// 2. Internal absolute imports (using @/ alias)
import { db } from '@/lib/db';
import { useChatStore } from '@/stores/useChatStore';
import { chatService } from '@/services/ChatService';

// 3. Component imports
import { Button } from '@/components/ui/Button';
import { ChatList } from '@/components/tabs/HistoryTab/ChatList';

// 4. Type imports (separate)
import type { Chat } from '@/types/chat';
import type { Folder } from '@/types/folder';

// 5. Relative imports (only if necessary)
import { formatDate } from './utils';
```

### Barrel Exports

**Use barrel exports for UI components:**
```typescript
// src/components/ui/index.ts
export { Button } from './Button';
export { Badge } from './Badge';
export { Card } from './Card';

// Usage
import { Button, Badge, Card } from '@/components/ui';
```

**DON'T use barrel exports for:**
- Stores (causes circular dependencies)
- Services (explicit imports are clearer)

## Naming Conventions

### Files

| Type | Convention | Example |
|------|-----------|---------|
| React Components | PascalCase.tsx | `AIAssistantTab.tsx` |
| Hooks | camelCase.ts | `useChatHistory.ts` |
| Services | PascalCase.ts | `ChatService.ts` |
| Types | camelCase.ts | `chat.ts` |
| Utils | camelCase.ts | `formatDate.ts` |
| Content Scripts | lowercase-hyphen.ts | `notebooklm.ts` |

### Variables & Functions

```typescript
// Constants: UPPER_SNAKE_CASE
const MAX_CHAT_LENGTH = 10000;
const API_BASE_URL = 'https://api.example.com';

// Variables: camelCase
const chatCount = 10;
const isLoading = false;

// Functions: camelCase (verb prefix)
function saveChat() {}
function fetchChats() {}
function isValidEmail() {}

// React Components: PascalCase
function ChatList() {}
function AIAssistantTab() {}

// Interfaces/Types: PascalCase
interface Chat {}
type SyncStatus = 'idle' | 'syncing';

// Private functions: _ prefix (optional, prefer scoping)
function _internalHelper() {}
```

### Boolean Naming

Prefix with `is`, `has`, `should`, `can`:

```typescript
const isLoading = false;
const hasError = true;
const shouldSync = false;
const canDelete = true;
```

## Testing Standards

### Unit Tests (Vitest)

**File Naming:** `[Component].test.ts` or `[Service].test.ts`

**Structure:**
```typescript
import { describe, it, expect, beforeEach, vi } from 'vitest';
import { chatService } from './ChatService';
import { db } from '@/lib/db';

describe('ChatService', () => {
  beforeEach(async () => {
    await db.chats.clear();
  });

  describe('saveChat', () => {
    it('should save chat to IndexedDB', async () => {
      const chat = await chatService.saveChat({
        notebookId: 'test-123',
        question: 'What is TypeScript?',
        answer: 'TypeScript is...',
        source: 'notebooklm',
        timestamp: new Date(),
        tags: ['typescript'],
        folderId: null,
        syncStatus: 'local',
      });

      expect(chat.id).toBeDefined();

      const saved = await db.chats.get(chat.id);
      expect(saved).toEqual(chat);
    });

    it('should trigger sync when cloud sync enabled', async () => {
      const syncSpy = vi.spyOn(chatService, 'syncChat');

      await chatService.saveChat({ /* ... */ });

      expect(syncSpy).toHaveBeenCalled();
    });
  });
});
```

### Integration Tests (Playwright)

**File Naming:** `[Feature].spec.ts`

```typescript
import { test, expect } from '@playwright/test';

test.describe('Auto-save functionality', () => {
  test('should auto-save NotebookLM chat', async ({ page, extensionId }) => {
    await page.goto('https://notebooklm.google.com');

    // Test implementation
  });
});
```

### Test Coverage Requirements

- **Unit Tests:** 80% code coverage minimum
- **Integration Tests:** All critical user flows
- **Accessibility Tests:** All UI components

## Performance Standards

### Code Splitting

**Route-level splitting:**
```typescript
const AIAssistantTab = lazy(() => import('./tabs/AIAssistantTab'));
const HistoryTab = lazy(() => import('./tabs/HistoryTab'));
```

**Bundle Size Targets:**
- Initial load: <500KB (gzipped)
- Each lazy-loaded tab: <150KB (gzipped)
- Total extension: <5MB

### Virtual Scrolling

**Always use virtual scrolling for lists >100 items:**
```typescript
import { FixedSizeList } from 'react-window';

function ChatHistoryList({ chats }: { chats: Chat[] }) {
  return (
    <FixedSizeList
      height={600}
      itemCount={chats.length}
      itemSize={72}
      width="100%"
    >
      {({ index, style }) => (
        <ChatItem chat={chats[index]} style={style} />
      )}
    </FixedSizeList>
  );
}
```

### IndexedDB Query Optimization

```typescript
// ‚úÖ Fast: Uses index
await db.chats.where('notebookId').equals(notebookId).toArray();

// ‚ùå Slow: Full table scan
await db.chats.filter(chat => chat.notebookId === notebookId).toArray();
```

## Accessibility Standards

### Semantic HTML

```tsx
// ‚úÖ Good: Semantic elements
<nav>
  <ul>
    <li><a href="/history">History</a></li>
  </ul>
</nav>

// ‚ùå Bad: Div soup
<div className="nav">
  <div className="nav-item">History</div>
</div>
```

### ARIA Attributes

```tsx
// Button with loading state
<button
  aria-busy={isLoading}
  aria-label="Save chat"
  disabled={isLoading}
>
  {isLoading ? 'Saving...' : 'Save'}
</button>

// Live region for announcements
<div aria-live="polite" aria-atomic="true">
  {notification}
</div>
```

### Keyboard Navigation

- All interactive elements must be keyboard accessible
- Implement focus management for modals
- Provide skip links for navigation

---

## Security Standards

### Content Security Policy

**Manifest V3 Compliance:**
- No `eval()` or `new Function()`
- No inline scripts
- All scripts in bundled files

### OAuth Token Storage

```typescript
// ‚úÖ Secure: chrome.storage.local
await chrome.storage.local.set({ authTokens: tokens });

// ‚ùå Insecure: chrome.storage.sync (syncs across devices)
await chrome.storage.sync.set({ authTokens: tokens });
```

### Input Validation

```typescript
// Always validate user input
function validateEmail(email: string): boolean {
  const emailRegex = /^[^\s@]+@[^\s@]+\.[^\s@]+$/;
  return emailRegex.test(email);
}

// Sanitize before rendering
import DOMPurify from 'dompurify';

function renderUserContent(html: string) {
  return DOMPurify.sanitize(html);
}
```

## Code Review Checklist

Before submitting code, verify:

- [ ] TypeScript strict mode passes with no errors
- [ ] All functions have explicit return types
- [ ] No `any` types without justification
- [ ] Components follow smart/dumb pattern
- [ ] State management uses Zustand correctly
- [ ] File naming conventions followed
- [ ] Import order is correct
- [ ] Unit tests pass with >80% coverage
- [ ] Accessibility: ARIA attributes where needed
- [ ] Performance: Virtual scrolling for large lists
- [ ] Security: No eval, proper token storage
- [ ] Bundle size within targets

---

## Enforcement

These standards are enforced via:

1. **ESLint**: Catches type errors, unused variables, import order
2. **Prettier**: Auto-formats code
3. **TypeScript Compiler**: Strict mode enforces type safety
4. **Vitest**: Enforces test coverage thresholds
5. **Code Review**: Manual verification of patterns and standards

## Directory Organization

### `/src/entrypoints/`
Chrome extension entry points managed by WXT:
- **background.ts** - Service worker for background tasks, message passing, and API session management
- **sidebar.tsx** - Main React application rendered in Chrome's side panel
- **options.tsx** - Optional settings page (separate from sidebar settings tab)
- **content/** - Content scripts for DOM scraping on different AI platforms

### `/src/components/`
React component hierarchy:
- **sidebar/** - Core layout components (header, footer, tab bar)
- **tabs/** - Main tab panel components (AI Assistant, History, Directory, Agents, Settings)
- **modals/** - Dialog components for onboarding, exports, agent progress, warnings
- **ui/** - Reusable presentational components from Shadcn/ui

### `/src/lib/`
Core libraries and utilities:
- **db.ts** - Dexie.js IndexedDB database initialization and schema
- **convex.ts** - Convex client setup and configuration
- **chrome-ai.ts** - Wrappers for Chrome Built-in AI APIs (Prompt, Rewriter, Summarizer, Translator)
- **utils.ts** - Shared utility functions

### `/src/stores/`
Zustand state management stores:
- **useUIStore.ts** - UI state (active tab, modals, sidebar width)
- **useChatStore.ts** - Chat history, folders, search state
- **useSyncStore.ts** - Cloud sync status and operations
- **useSettingsStore.ts** - User preferences, capture settings, storage quota

### `/src/services/`
Business logic and data access layer:
- **ChatService.ts** - Chat CRUD operations, search, bulk operations
- **AudioService.ts** - Audio overview management and storage
- **SyncService.ts** - Convex synchronization logic
- **AgentService.ts** - Multi-step agent orchestration

### `/src/types/`
TypeScript type definitions:
- Shared interfaces and types for chat, folder, agent, sync models

### `/convex/`
Convex backend functions:
- **schema.ts** - Database schema definitions
- **auth.config.ts** - Better Auth configuration for Google OAuth
- **notebooks.ts** - Mutations and queries for public notebook directory
- **users.ts** - User management functions
- **http.ts** - HTTP endpoints for webhooks

## File Naming Conventions

- **React Components**: PascalCase (e.g., `AIAssistantTab.tsx`)
- **Hooks**: camelCase with `use` prefix (e.g., `useUIStore.ts`)
- **Services**: PascalCase with `Service` suffix (e.g., `ChatService.ts`)
- **Types**: camelCase for files, PascalCase for interfaces (e.g., `chat.ts` exports `Chat` interface)
- **Content Scripts**: lowercase with hyphen separator (e.g., `notebooklm.ts`)
- **Config Files**: lowercase with extension (e.g., `wxt.config.ts`)

## Import Aliases

```typescript
// Configured in tsconfig.json
import { db } from '@/lib/db';
import { useChatStore } from '@/stores/useChatStore';
import { chatService } from '@/services/ChatService';
import { Button } from '@/components/ui/Button';
import type { Chat } from '@/types/chat';
```

**Alias**: `@/` maps to `src/`

# Story 1.6: Better Auth + Convex Google Authentication Integration

## Status
- **Version**: 1.2
- **Status**: Approved
- **Created**: 2025-10-11
- **Last Updated**: 2025-10-11
- **Epic**: Epic 1 - Foundation & AI Sidebar
- **Story Points**: 5
- **Priority**: High
- **Assignee**: Dev Agent
- **Dependencies**: Story 1.1 (WXT Extension Setup)

## Story

### Title
Implement Better Auth with Convex for Google OAuth Authentication

### Description
As a user, I want to securely authenticate with my Google account so that I can access personalized features and sync my data across devices.

**Context**: This story implements a unified authentication solution using Better Auth (@convex-dev/better-auth) with Google OAuth provider integration. Better Auth provides built-in OAuth 2.0 support and seamless Convex backend integration. The authentication backend will be shared between the Chrome extension and a future complementary Next.js website, enabling unified user accounts and cross-platform experiences.

**Value**: Enables secure user authentication, personalized experiences, and prepares the foundation for:
- Cross-device data synchronization
- User-specific settings and preferences
- Future Next.js website with same authentication backend
- Unified user database across extension and website

### User Story
```
AS A user of the SuperNotebookLM Chrome Extension
I WANT TO authenticate using my Google account
SO THAT I can securely access personalized features and sync my data across devices
```

### Technical Approach
Implement Better Auth with Convex integration following the architecture specification:

1. **Convex Backend Setup** (Shared with Future Website):
   - Install `better-auth@1.3.8` (exact version) and `@convex-dev/better-auth`
   - Register Better Auth component in `convex/convex.config.ts`
   - Create auth configuration in `convex/auth.config.ts`
   - Set up auth instance in `convex/auth.ts` with Google provider
   - Mount HTTP handlers in `convex/http.ts` (hosted on Convex infrastructure)

2. **Environment Configuration**:
   - Generate `BETTER_AUTH_SECRET` for Convex deployment
   - Configure `SITE_URL` pointing to Convex site URL
   - Add Chrome extension origin to `trustedOrigins`
   - Set up Google Cloud Console OAuth credentials
   - Configure redirect URIs pointing to Convex endpoints (NOT extension URLs)

3. **Chrome Extension Integration** (WXT Framework):
   - Create auth client using `better-auth/react` (NOT `better-auth/client`)
   - Configure client `baseURL` to point to Convex site URL
   - Implement `ConvexBetterAuthProvider` wrapper in extension contexts
   - Handle OAuth flow using Better Auth's popup-based social sign-in
   - NO Next.js API routes in extension (handled by Convex)
   - NO chrome.identity API needed (Better Auth handles popup flow)

4. **Session & Token Management**:
   - Leverage Better Auth's automatic token refresh
   - Implement session persistence using Convex's built-in session storage
   - Handle authentication state in Zustand store
   - Sync auth state across extension contexts (popup, sidepanel, background)

5. **Future Website Integration** (Not in This Story):
   - Same Convex backend will serve Next.js website
   - Next.js website will add `app/api/auth/[...all]/route.ts` proxy handlers
   - Unified user database and session management
   - Users can authenticate from extension OR website interchangeably

## Acceptance Criteria

### Must Have (P0)
- [ ] **AC1**: Better Auth component registered and configured in Convex project
  - `convex/convex.config.ts` includes `@convex-dev/better-auth` component
  - `convex/auth.config.ts` configured with Convex site URL
  - `convex/auth.ts` implements `createAuth()` with Google social provider
  - `convex/http.ts` mounts Better Auth route handlers (accessible at `https://[deployment].convex.site`)

- [ ] **AC2**: Google OAuth provider configured and operational
  - Google Cloud Console project created with OAuth 2.0 credentials
  - Client ID and Client Secret stored as Convex environment variables
  - Redirect URIs configured to Convex endpoints: `https://[deployment].convex.site/api/auth/callback/google`
  - OAuth consent screen configured with required scopes (email, profile)

- [ ] **AC3**: Chrome extension auth client implemented (WXT framework)
  - `src/lib/auth-client.ts` creates Better Auth client with `convexClient()` plugin
  - Client `baseURL` points to Convex site URL (NOT localhost)
  - `ConvexBetterAuthProvider` wraps app in popup and sidepanel
  - Sign-in button triggers `authClient.signIn.social({ provider: "google" })`
  - OAuth flow opens popup window (NOT using chrome.identity API)
  - Successfully completes OAuth flow via Convex callback and returns to extension

- [ ] **AC4**: Session management functional across extension contexts
  - User session persists after popup/sidepanel close and reopen
  - Authentication state accessible in background service worker
  - `getCurrentUser` Convex query returns user data when authenticated
  - Session automatically refreshes when access token expires

- [ ] **AC5**: Environment variables and secrets configured
  - `BETTER_AUTH_SECRET` generated and set in Convex deployment
  - `SITE_URL` set to Convex site URL in Convex environment
  - Chrome extension origin added to `trustedOrigins` in `convex/auth.ts`
  - `VITE_CONVEX_URL` and `VITE_CONVEX_SITE_URL` in extension `.env`
  - `GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID` and `GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET` in Convex environment

### Should Have (P1)
- [ ] **AC6**: Sign-out functionality implemented
  - Sign-out button calls `authClient.signOut()`
  - Clears user session from Convex
  - Updates UI to show signed-out state
  - Redirects to authentication prompt

- [ ] **AC7**: User profile display in UI
  - Display user's Google profile name in sidebar header
  - Show user's Google profile picture (avatar)
  - Display email address in settings/profile section

- [ ] **AC8**: Error handling for auth failures
  - Handle OAuth cancellation (user closes popup)
  - Display error message for network failures
  - Retry mechanism for transient errors
  - Clear error states on successful retry

### Could Have (P2)
- [ ] **AC9**: Auth state persistence across browser restarts
  - Session persists even after browser restart
  - Automatic re-authentication if refresh token valid
  - Background session refresh without user interaction

- [ ] **AC10**: CORS and trusted origins configuration
  - Convex HTTP endpoints properly configured for extension origin
  - Extension manifest includes host_permissions for Convex URLs
  - Document trusted origins setup for future website

### Task 1: Convex Backend Better Auth Setup
**Estimated Time**: 4 hours

#### Subtasks:
- [ ] **1.1**: Install Better Auth packages

    ```ts

    import betterAuth from "@convex-dev/better-auth/convex.config";

    const app = defineApp();
    app.use(betterAuth);

- [ ] **1.3**: Create auth configuration file
  - Create `convex/auth.config.ts`:

- [ ] **1.4**: Set environment variables in Convex
  - Generate secret: `npx convex env set BETTER_AUTH_SECRET=$(openssl rand -base64 32)`
  - Set site URL: `npx convex env set SITE_URL https://your-deployment.convex.site`
  - Set Google credentials: `npx convex env set GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID your-client-id`
  - Set Google secret: `npx convex env set GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET your-client-secret`
  - Verify environment variables in Convex dashboard

- [ ] **1.5**: Create Better Auth instance with Google provider
  - Create `convex/auth.ts` with:
    ```ts
    import { createClient, type GenericCtx } from "@convex-dev/better-auth";
    import { convex } from "@convex-dev/better-auth/plugins";
    import { components } from "./_generated/api";
    import { DataModel } from "./_generated/dataModel";
    import { query } from "./_generated/server";
    import { betterAuth } from "better-auth";

    const siteUrl = process.env.SITE_URL!;

    export const authComponent = createClient<DataModel>(components.betterAuth);

    export const createAuth = (
      ctx: GenericCtx<DataModel>,
      { optionsOnly } = { optionsOnly: false },
    ) => {
      return betterAuth({
        logger: {
          disabled: optionsOnly,
        },
        baseURL: siteUrl,
        trustedOrigins: [
          // Chrome extension origin (replace with actual extension ID)
          "chrome-extension://YOUR_EXTENSION_ID",
          // Add future Next.js website origin when ready
          // "https://your-website.com",
        ],
        database: authComponent.adapter(ctx),
        socialProviders: {
          google: {
            clientId: process.env.GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID as string,
            clientSecret: process.env.GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET as string,
          },
        },
        plugins: [convex()],
      });
    };

    export const getCurrentUser = query({
      args: {},
      handler: async (ctx) => {
        return authComponent.getAuthUser(ctx);
      },
    });
    ```

- [ ] **1.6**: Mount HTTP handlers in Convex
  - Create or update `convex/http.ts`:
    ```ts
    import { httpRouter } from "convex/server";
    import { authComponent, createAuth } from "./auth";

    const http = httpRouter();

    // Register Better Auth routes - these will be hosted on Convex infrastructure
    // Accessible at https://your-deployment.convex.site/api/auth/*
    authComponent.registerRoutes(http, createAuth);

    export default http;
    ```
  - Verify HTTP routes are deployed by running `npx convex dev`
  - Test endpoint accessibility: `curl https://your-deployment.convex.site/api/auth/session`

- [ ] **3.3**: Create auth client library
  - Create `src/lib/auth-client.ts`:
    ```ts
    import { createAuthClient } from "better-auth/react";
    import { convexClient } from "@convex-dev/better-auth/client/plugins";

    export const authClient = createAuthClient({
      // Point to Convex site URL, NOT localhost
      baseURL: import.meta.env.VITE_CONVEX_SITE_URL,
      plugins: [convexClient()],
    });

    // Export session hook for convenience
    export const useSession = authClient.useSession;
    ```

- [ ] **3.4**: Set up Convex client provider
  - Create `src/components/providers/ConvexClientProvider.tsx`:
    ```tsx
    import { ReactNode } from "react";
    import { ConvexReactClient } from "convex/react";
    import { authClient } from "@/lib/auth-client";
    import { ConvexBetterAuthProvider } from "@convex-dev/better-auth/react";

    const convex = new ConvexReactClient(import.meta.env.VITE_CONVEX_URL, {
      // Optionally pause queries until authenticated
      // expectAuth: true,
    });

    export function ConvexClientProvider({ children }: { children: ReactNode }) {
      return (
        <ConvexBetterAuthProvider client={convex} authClient={authClient}>
          {children}
        </ConvexBetterAuthProvider>
      );
    }
    ```

- [ ] **3.5**: Wrap extension entry points with provider
  - Update `entrypoints/sidepanel/App.tsx`:

    export default function App() {
      return (
        <ConvexClientProvider>
          {/* Existing sidebar content */}
        </ConvexClientProvider>
      );
    }
    ```
  - Update `entrypoints/popup/App.tsx` similarly

- [ ] **3.6**: Create sign-in UI component
  - Create `src/components/auth/SignInButton.tsx`:
    ```tsx
    import { useState } from "react";
    import { authClient } from "@/lib/auth-client";

    export function SignInButton() {
      const [loading, setLoading] = useState(false);
      const [error, setError] = useState<string | null>(null);

      const handleSignIn = async () => {
        try {
          setLoading(true);
          setError(null);
          // This will open a popup window for OAuth flow
          await authClient.signIn.social({ provider: "google" });
        } catch (err) {
          setError(err instanceof Error ? err.message : "Failed to sign in");
        } finally {
          setLoading(false);
        }
      };

      return (
        <div>
          <button
            onClick={handleSignIn}
            disabled={loading}
            className="btn-primary"
          >
            {loading ? "Signing in..." : "Sign in with Google"}
          </button>

### Critical Architecture Notes

#### üö® Chrome Extension OAuth Flow (Better Auth Popup Method)
```
1. User clicks "Sign in with Google" in extension
   ‚Üì
2. authClient.signIn.social({ provider: "google" }) called
   ‚Üì
3. Better Auth opens popup window (standard web popup, NOT chrome.identity)
   ‚Üì
4. Popup navigates to: https://your-deployment.convex.site/api/auth/signin/google
   ‚Üì
5. Convex redirects to Google OAuth consent screen
   ‚Üì
6. User grants consent on Google
   ‚Üì
7. Google redirects to: https://your-deployment.convex.site/api/auth/callback/google
   ‚Üì
8. Convex Better Auth handles callback, exchanges code for tokens, creates session
   ‚Üì
9. Convex returns session to extension via popup window
   ‚Üì
10. Better Auth client stores session, popup closes
   ‚Üì
11. Extension now authenticated, can make Convex queries with user context
```

#### üîë Key Differences from Standard Web App
- **NO** Next.js API routes in extension (`app/api/auth/[...all]/route.ts` NOT used)
- **NO** `chrome.identity` API needed (Better Auth handles popup directly)
- **YES** Standard Better Auth popup flow works in extension contexts
- **YES** Convex HTTP endpoints handle all OAuth callbacks
- **YES** Extension just needs `host_permissions` for Convex URLs
- **NOTE**: Epic initially mentioned chrome.identity, but Better Auth provides better integration

#### üåê Future Website Integration
When you create the complementary Next.js website:

1. **Add Next.js proxy handlers** (makes auth work in Next.js server components):
   ```ts
   // app/api/auth/[...all]/route.ts
   import { nextJsHandler } from "@convex-dev/better-auth/nextjs";
   export const { GET, POST } = nextJsHandler();
   ```

2. **Add website origin to trusted origins**:
   ```ts
   // convex/auth.ts
   trustedOrigins: [
     "chrome-extension://YOUR_EXTENSION_ID",
     "https://your-website.com", // Add this
   ],
   ```

3. **Same auth client in website**:
   ```ts
   // website/lib/auth-client.ts (same as extension!)
   import { createAuthClient } from "better-auth/react";
   import { convexClient } from "@convex-dev/better-auth/client/plugins";

   export const authClient = createAuthClient({
     baseURL: process.env.NEXT_PUBLIC_CONVEX_SITE_URL,
     plugins: [convexClient()],
   });
   ```

4. **Benefits**:
   - ‚úÖ Same user database (Convex)
   - ‚úÖ Users can sign in from extension OR website
   - ‚úÖ Sessions work across both platforms
   - ‚úÖ No duplicate auth infrastructure
   - ‚úÖ Unified analytics and user tracking

### Integration Points
- **Story 1.5 (Smart Query Assistant)**: Auth state will integrate with query history to enable user-specific search history stored in Convex
- **Future Story (Data Sync)**: Auth session will enable cross-device data synchronization via Convex
- **Future Story (AI Features)**: User context will personalize AI responses
- **Future Epic (Website)**: Same Better Auth backend powers companion website

### Security Considerations
- **Credentials Storage**: Google OAuth credentials stored in Convex environment ONLY (never in extension code)
- **HTTPS Only**: All OAuth redirects point to HTTPS Convex endpoints
- **Trusted Origins**: Extension origin must be added to `trustedOrigins` in `convex/auth.ts`
- **Scope Minimization**: Request only `email` and `profile` scopes initially
- **CSP Compliance**: Extension manifest must allow requests to `*.convex.site` and `*.convex.cloud`
- **Token Security**: Better Auth manages token storage securely (uses HTTP-only cookies in web, secure storage in extension)

### Known Limitations
- Better Auth version must be exactly 1.3.8 due to Convex compatibility
- OAuth flow requires popup window (can be blocked by popup blockers)
- Extension ID must be known and added to `trustedOrigins` before production deployment
- Convex free tier has usage limits (upgrade for production)

### Future Enhancements
- Support for additional OAuth providers (Microsoft, GitHub) for website
- Implement refresh token rotation for enhanced security
- Add multi-account support
- Implement scope upgrade flow for Drive/Gmail access using `linkSocial()`
- Add email/password auth for users who prefer not to use Google
- Implement magic link authentication option
- Add two-factor authentication (2FA) support

### Troubleshooting Guide

#### Common Issues:

1. **"CORS error" when signing in**
   - Solution: Verify extension ID is added to `trustedOrigins` in `convex/auth.ts`
   - Solution: Check extension manifest has `host_permissions` for Convex URLs

2. **"Popup blocked" error**
   - Solution: User needs to allow popups for extension
   - Solution: Show UI hint to enable popups

3. **"Redirect URI mismatch" from Google**
   - Solution: Verify Google Cloud Console has exact Convex URL in authorized redirect URIs
   - Format: `https://your-deployment.convex.site/api/auth/callback/google`

4. **Session doesn't persist after extension reload**
   - Solution: Verify Better Auth session storage is working
   - Solution: Check browser storage permissions

5. **"baseURL" errors in auth client**
   - Solution: Verify `.env` has `VITE_CONVEX_SITE_URL` set correctly
   - Solution: Must end in `.convex.site`, not `.convex.cloud`

## üêõ Troubleshooting

### Issue: Still seeing "Loading session..." forever
**Symptoms**:
- Console shows `isPending: false`, `session: null`
- Network tab shows 200 OK responses with cookies

**Solutions**:
1. **First, verify Google credentials are set in Convex**:
   ```bash
   npx convex env list
   ```
   If `GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID` or `GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET` are missing, set them and redeploy:
   ```bash
   npx convex env set GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID "YOUR_ID"
   npx convex env set GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET "YOUR_SECRET"
   npx convex deploy
   ```

2. **Clear ALL extension data**:
   - Completely remove and reinstall the extension
   - Clear browser cookies for `*.convex.site` and `*.convex.cloud`

3. **Check Convex logs**:
   ```bash
   npx convex logs
   ```
   Look for errors during OAuth callback processing

4. **Verify trustedOrigins**:
   - Open `convex/auth.ts`
   - Confirm extension ID matches: `chrome-extension://jegoogflhaohfcclehodbfmpfajkjlem`
   - If you're using a different extension ID, update it and redeploy

### Issue: "Popup blocked" error
**Solution**: Allow popups for the extension in Chrome settings

### Issue: "Redirect URI mismatch" from Google
**Solution**: Double-check the redirect URI in Google Console matches exactly:
```
https://cheery-salmon-841.convex.site/api/auth/callback/google
```

### Issue: "CORS error" when signing in
**Solution**: Make sure you:
1. Added the extension ID to `convex/auth.ts` trustedOrigins
2. Ran `npx convex deploy` after updating

### Issue: Session doesn't persist after refresh
**Solution**:
1. Check that the extension has storage permissions (already configured)
2. Verify session expiry settings in `convex/auth.ts` (already set to 7 days)
3. Check browser console for any error messages

### Issue: Verification table populated but no user created
**Symptoms**:
- Convex `verification` table has entries
- `user` table is empty
- Session remains null

**Solution**: This was likely caused by the missing account linking configuration, which has now been added. Clear all data and try again:
1. Delete all entries from the `verification` table in Convex dashboard
2. Clear extension data and reload
3. Try signing in again
4. The user should now be created in the `user` table

## Prerequisites

<Steps>
  <Step>

    To use Convex + Better Auth, you'll first need a [Convex](https://www.convex.dev/) project.
    If you don't have one, run the following command to get started.

    <CodeBlockTabs defaultValue="npm">

          npm
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>

        ```

## Installation of Convex + Better Auth

The following documentation assumes you're using Next.js.

If you're not using Next.js, please refer to the [installation guide by Convex](https://convex-better-auth.netlify.app/#select-your-framework).

<Callout>
  For a complete example, check out Convex + Better Auth example with Next.js in this [Github repository](https://github.com/get-convex/better-auth/tree/main/examples/next).
</Callout>

### Installation

<Steps>
  <Step>
    #### Install packages

    Install the component, a pinned version of Better Auth, and ensure the latest version of Convex.

    <Callout>
      This component requires Convex `1.25.0` or later.
    </Callout>

    <CodeBlockTabs defaultValue="npm">
      <CodeBlockTabsList>
        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="npm">
          npm
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>

        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="pnpm">
          pnpm
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>

        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="yarn">
          yarn
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>

        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="bun">
          bun
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>
      </CodeBlockTabsList>

      <CodeBlockTab value="npm">
        ```bash
        npm install better-auth@1.3.8 --save-exact
        npm install convex@latest @convex-dev/better-auth
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>

      <CodeBlockTab value="pnpm">
        ```bash
        pnpm add better-auth@1.3.8 --save-exact
        pnpm add convex@latest @convex-dev/better-auth
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>

      <CodeBlockTab value="yarn">
        ```bash
        yarn add better-auth@1.3.8 --exact
        yarn add convex@latest @convex-dev/better-auth
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>

      <CodeBlockTab value="bun">
        ```bash
        bun add better-auth@1.3.8 --exact
        bun add convex@latest @convex-dev/better-auth
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>
    </CodeBlockTabs>
  </Step>

  <Step>
    #### Register the component

    Register the Better Auth component in your Convex project.

    ```ts title="convex/convex.config.ts"
    import { defineApp } from "convex/server";
    import betterAuth from "@convex-dev/better-auth/convex.config";

    const app = defineApp();
    app.use(betterAuth);

    export default app;
    ```
  </Step>

  <Step>
    #### Add Convex auth config

    Add a `convex/auth.config.ts` file to configure Better Auth as an authentication provider.

    ```ts title="convex/auth.config.ts"
    export default {
        providers: [
            {
                domain: process.env.CONVEX_SITE_URL,
                applicationID: "convex",
            },
        ],
    };
    ```
  </Step>

  <Step>
    #### Set environment variables

    Generate a secret for encryption and generating hashes. Use the command below if you have openssl installed,
    or use the button to generate a random value instead. Or generate your own however you like.

    <CodeBlockTabs defaultValue="npm">
      <CodeBlockTabsList>
        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="npm">
          npm
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>

        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="pnpm">
          pnpm
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>

        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="yarn">
          yarn
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>

        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="bun">
          bun
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>
      </CodeBlockTabsList>

      <CodeBlockTab value="npm">
        ```bash
        npx convex env set BETTER_AUTH_SECRET=$(openssl rand -base64 32)
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>

      <CodeBlockTab value="pnpm">
        ```bash
        pnpm dlx convex env set BETTER_AUTH_SECRET=$(openssl rand -base64 32)
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>

      <CodeBlockTab value="yarn">
        ```bash
        yarn dlx convex env set BETTER_AUTH_SECRET=$(openssl rand -base64 32)
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>

      <CodeBlockTab value="bun">
        ```bash
        bun x convex env set BETTER_AUTH_SECRET=$(openssl rand -base64 32)
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>
    </CodeBlockTabs>

    Add your site URL to your Convex deployment.

    <CodeBlockTabs defaultValue="npm">
      <CodeBlockTabsList>
        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="npm">
          npm
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>

        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="pnpm">
          pnpm
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>

        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="yarn">
          yarn
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>

        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="bun">
          bun
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>
      </CodeBlockTabsList>

      <CodeBlockTab value="npm">
        ```bash
        npx convex env set SITE_URL http://localhost:3000
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>

      <CodeBlockTab value="pnpm">
        ```bash
        pnpm dlx convex env set SITE_URL http://localhost:3000
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>

      <CodeBlockTab value="yarn">
        ```bash
        yarn dlx convex env set SITE_URL http://localhost:3000
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>

      <CodeBlockTab value="bun">
        ```bash
        bun x convex env set SITE_URL http://localhost:3000
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>
    </CodeBlockTabs>

    Add environment variables to the `.env.local` file created by `npx convex dev`.
    It will be picked up by your framework dev server.

    ```shell title=".env.local" tab="Cloud"
    # Deployment used by \`npx convex dev\`
    CONVEX_DEPLOYMENT=dev:adjective-animal-123 # team: team-name, project: project-name

    NEXT_PUBLIC_CONVEX_URL=https://adjective-animal-123.convex.cloud

    # Same as NEXT_PUBLIC_CONVEX_URL but ends in .site // [!code ++]
    NEXT_PUBLIC_CONVEX_SITE_URL=https://adjective-animal-123.convex.site # [!code ++]

    # Your local site URL // [!code ++]
    SITE_URL=http://localhost:3000 # [!code ++]
    ```

    ```shell title=".env.local" tab="Self hosted"
    # Deployment used by \`npx convex dev\`
    CONVEX_DEPLOYMENT=dev:adjective-animal-123 # team: team-name, project: project-name

    NEXT_PUBLIC_CONVEX_URL=http://127.0.0.1:3210

    # Will generally be one number higher than NEXT_PUBLIC_CONVEX_URL,
    # so if your convex url is :3212, your site url will be :3213
    NEXT_PUBLIC_CONVEX_SITE_URL=http://127.0.0.1:3211 # [!code ++]

    # Your local site URL // [!code ++]
    SITE_URL=http://localhost:3000 # [!code ++]
    ```
  </Step>

  <Step>
    ### Create a Better Auth instance

    Create a Better Auth instance and initialize the component.

    <Callout>Some TypeScript errors will show until you save the file.</Callout>

    ```ts title="convex/auth.ts"
    import { createClient, type GenericCtx } from "@convex-dev/better-auth";
    import { convex } from "@convex-dev/better-auth/plugins";
    import { components } from "./_generated/api";
    import { DataModel } from "./_generated/dataModel";
    import { query } from "./_generated/server";
    import { betterAuth } from "better-auth";

    const siteUrl = process.env.SITE_URL!;

    // The component client has methods needed for integrating Convex with Better Auth,
    // as well as helper methods for general use.
    export const authComponent = createClient<DataModel>(components.betterAuth);

    export const createAuth = (
        ctx: GenericCtx<DataModel>,
            { optionsOnly } = { optionsOnly: false },
        ) => {
          return betterAuth({
            // disable logging when createAuth is called just to generate options.
            // this is not required, but there's a lot of noise in logs without it.
            logger: {
                disabled: optionsOnly,
            },
            baseURL: siteUrl,
            database: authComponent.adapter(ctx),
            // Configure simple, non-verified email/password to get started
            emailAndPassword: {
                enabled: true,
                requireEmailVerification: false,
            },
            plugins: [
                // The Convex plugin is required for Convex compatibility
                convex(),
            ],
        });
    };

    // Example function for getting the current user
    // Feel free to edit, omit, etc.
    export const getCurrentUser = query({
        args: {},
        handler: async (ctx) => {
            return authComponent.getAuthUser(ctx);
        },
    });
    ```
  </Step>

  <Step>
    ### Create a Better Auth client instance

    Create a Better Auth client instance for interacting with the Better Auth server from your client.

    ```ts title="src/lib/auth-client.ts"
    import { createAuthClient } from "better-auth/react";
    import { convexClient } from "@convex-dev/better-auth/client/plugins";

    export const authClient = createAuthClient({
        plugins: [convexClient()],
    });
    ```
  </Step>

  <Step>
    ### Mount handlers

    Register Better Auth route handlers on your Convex deployment.

    ```ts title="convex/http.ts"
    import { httpRouter } from "convex/server";
    import { authComponent, createAuth } from "./auth";

    const http = httpRouter();

    authComponent.registerRoutes(http, createAuth);

    export default http;
    ```

    Set up route handlers to proxy auth requests from your framework server to your Convex deployment.

    ```ts title="app/api/auth/[...all]/route.ts"
    import { nextJsHandler } from "@convex-dev/better-auth/nextjs";

    export const { GET, POST } = nextJsHandler();
    ```
  </Step>

  <Step>
    ### Set up Convex client provider

    Wrap your app with the `ConvexBetterAuthProvider` component.

    ```ts title="app/ConvexClientProvider.tsx"
    "use client";

    import { ReactNode } from "react";
    import { ConvexReactClient } from "convex/react";
    import { authClient } from "@/lib/auth-client"; // [!code ++]
    import { ConvexBetterAuthProvider } from "@convex-dev/better-auth/react"; // [!code ++]

    const convex = new ConvexReactClient(process.env.NEXT_PUBLIC_CONVEX_URL!, {
      // Optionally pause queries until the user is authenticated // [!code ++]
      expectAuth: true, // [!code ++]
    });

    export function ConvexClientProvider({ children }: { children: ReactNode }) {
      return (
        <ConvexBetterAuthProvider client={convex} authClient={authClient}> // [!code ++]
          {children}
        </ConvexBetterAuthProvider> // [!code ++]
      );
    }
    ```
  </Step>
</Steps>

### You're done!

You're now ready to start using Better Auth with Convex.

## Usage

### Using Better Auth from the server

To use Better Auth's [server
methods](https://www.better-auth.com/docs/concepts/api) in server rendering,
server functions, or any other Next.js server code, use Convex functions
and call the function from your server code.

First, a token helper for calling Convex functions from your server code.

```ts title="src/lib/auth-server.ts"
import { createAuth } from "@/convex/auth";
import { getToken as getTokenNextjs } from "@convex-dev/better-auth/nextjs";

export const getToken = () => {
  return getTokenNextjs(createAuth);
};
```

Here's an example Convex function that uses Better Auth's server methods, and
a server action that calls the Convex function.

```ts title="convex/users.ts"
import { mutation } from "./_generated/server";
import { v } from "convex/values";
import { createAuth, authComponent } from "./auth";

export const updateUserPassword = mutation({
  args: {
    currentPassword: v.string(),
    newPassword: v.string(),
  },
  handler: async (ctx, args) => {
    await createAuth(ctx).api.changePassword({
      body: {
        currentPassword: args.currentPassword,
        newPassword: args.newPassword,
      },
      headers: await authComponent.getHeaders(ctx),
    });
  },
});
```

```ts title="app/actions.ts"
"use server";

import { fetchMutation } from "convex/nextjs";
import { api } from "../convex/_generated/api";
import { getToken } from "../lib/auth-server";

// Authenticated mutation via server function
export async function updatePassword({
  currentPassword,
  newPassword,
}: {
  currentPassword: string;
  newPassword: string;
}) {
  const token = await getToken();
  await fetchMutation(
    api.users.updatePassword,
    { currentPassword, newPassword },
    { token }
  );
}
```

<Callout>
  This documentation comes from the [Convex documentation](https://convex-better-auth.netlify.app/),
  for more information, please refer to their documentation.
</Callout>

# concepts: OAuth
URL: /docs/concepts/oauth
Source: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/better-auth/better-auth/refs/heads/main/docs/content/docs/concepts/oauth.mdx

How Better Auth handles OAuth
        
***

title: OAuth
description: How Better Auth handles OAuth
------------------------------------------

Better Auth comes with built-in support for OAuth 2.0 and OpenID Connect. This allows you to authenticate users via popular OAuth providers like Google, Facebook, GitHub, and more.

If your desired provider isn't directly supported, you can use the [Generic OAuth Plugin](/docs/plugins/generic-oauth) for custom integrations.

## Configuring Social Providers

To enable a social provider, you need to provide `clientId` and `clientSecret` for the provider.

Here's an example of how to configure Google as a provider:

```ts title="auth.ts"
import { betterAuth } from "better-auth";

export const auth = betterAuth({
  // Other configurations...
  socialProviders: {
    google: {
      clientId: "YOUR_GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID",
      clientSecret: "YOUR_GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET",
    },
  },
});
```

## Usage

### Sign In

To sign in with a social provider, you can use the `signIn.social` function with the `authClient` or `auth.api` for server-side usage.

```ts
// client-side usage
await authClient.signIn.social({
  provider: "google", // or any other provider id
})
```

```ts
// server-side usage
await auth.api.signInSocial({
  body: {
    provider: "google", // or any other provider id
  },
});
```

### Link account

To link an account to a social provider, you can use the `linkAccount` function with the `authClient` or `auth.api` for server-side usage.

```ts
await authClient.linkSocial({
  provider: "google", // or any other provider id
})
```

server-side usage:

```ts
await auth.api.linkSocialAccount({
  body: {
    provider: "google", // or any other provider id
  },
  headers: // pass headers with authenticated token
});
```

### Get Access Token

To get the access token for a social provider, you can use the `getAccessToken` function with the `authClient` or `auth.api` for server-side usage. When you use this endpoint, if the access token is expired, it will be refreshed.

```ts
const { accessToken } = await authClient.getAccessToken({
  providerId: "google", // or any other provider id
  accountId: "accountId", // optional, if you want to get the access token for a specific account
})
```

server-side usage:

```ts
await auth.api.getAccessToken({
  body: {
    providerId: "google", // or any other provider id
    accountId: "accountId", // optional, if you want to get the access token for a specific account
    userId: "userId", // optional, if you don't provide headers with authenticated token
  },
  headers: // pass headers with authenticated token
});
```

### Get Account Info Provided by the provider

To get provider specific account info you can use the `accountInfo` function with the `authClient` or `auth.api` for server-side usage.

```ts
const info = await authClient.accountInfo({
  accountId: "accountId", // here you pass in the provider given account id, the provider is automatically detected from the account id
})
```

server-side usage:

```ts
await auth.api.accountInfo({
  body: { accountId: "accountId" },
  headers: // pass headers with authenticated token
});
```

### Requesting Additional Scopes

Sometimes your application may need additional OAuth scopes after the user has already signed up (e.g., for accessing GitHub repositories or Google Drive). Users may not want to grant extensive permissions initially, preferring to start with minimal permissions and grant additional access as needed.

You can request additional scopes by using the `linkSocial` method with the same provider. This will trigger a new OAuth flow that requests the additional scopes while maintaining the existing account connection.

```ts
const requestAdditionalScopes = async () => {
    await authClient.linkSocial({
        provider: "google",
        scopes: ["https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file"],
    });
};
```

<Callout>
  Make sure you're running Better Auth version 1.2.7 or later. Earlier versions (like 1.2.2) may show a "Social account already linked" error when trying to link with an existing provider for additional scopes.
</Callout>

## Provider Options

### scope

The scope of the access request. For example, `email` or `profile`.

```ts title="auth.ts"
import { betterAuth } from "better-auth";

export const auth = betterAuth({
  // Other configurations...
  socialProviders: {
    google: {
      clientId: "YOUR_GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID",
      clientSecret: "YOUR_GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET",
      scope: ["email", "profile"],
    },
  },
});
```

### redirectURI

Custom redirect URI for the provider. By default, it uses `/api/auth/callback/${providerName}`

```ts title="auth.ts"

export const auth = betterAuth({
  // Other configurations...
  socialProviders: {
    google: {
      clientId: "YOUR_GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID",
      clientSecret: "YOUR_GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET",
      redirectURI: "https://your-app.com/auth/callback",
    },
  },
});
```

### disableSignUp

Disables sign-up for new users.

### disableIdTokenSignIn

Disables the use of the ID token for sign-in. By default, it's enabled for some providers like Google and Apple.

### verifyIdToken

A custom function to verify the ID token.

### overrideUserInfoOnSignIn

A boolean value that determines whether to override the user information in the database when signing in. By default, it is set to `false`, meaning that the user information will not be overridden during sign-in. If you want to update the user information every time they sign in, set this to `true`.

### mapProfileToUser

A custom function to map the user profile returned from the provider to the user object in your database.

Useful, if you have additional fields in your user object you want to populate from the provider's profile. Or if you want to change how by default the user object is mapped.

```ts title="auth.ts"
import { betterAuth } from "better-auth";

export const auth = betterAuth({
  // Other configurations...
  socialProviders: {
    google: {
      clientId: "YOUR_GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID",
      clientSecret: "YOUR_GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET",
      mapProfileToUser: (profile) => {
        return {
          firstName: profile.given_name,
          lastName: profile.family_name,
        };
      },
    },
  },
});
```

### refreshAccessToken

A custom function to refresh the token. This feature is only supported for built-in social providers (Google, Facebook, GitHub, etc.) and is not currently supported for custom OAuth providers configured through the Generic OAuth Plugin. For built-in providers, you can provide a custom function to refresh the token if needed.

```ts title="auth.ts"
import { betterAuth } from "better-auth";

export const auth = betterAuth({
  // Other configurations...
  socialProviders: {
    google: {
      clientId: "YOUR_GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID",
      clientSecret: "YOUR_GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET",
      refreshAccessToken: async (token) => {
        return {
          accessToken: "new-access-token",
          refreshToken: "new-refresh-token",
        };
      },
    },
  },
});
```

### clientKey

The client key of your application. This is used by TikTok Social Provider instead of `clientId`.

```ts title="auth.ts"
import { betterAuth } from "better-auth";

export const auth = betterAuth({
  // Other configurations...
  socialProviders: {
    tiktok: {
      clientKey: "YOUR_TIKTOK_CLIENT_KEY",
      clientSecret: "YOUR_TIKTOK_CLIENT_SECRET",
    },
  },
});
```

### getUserInfo

A custom function to get user info from the provider. This allows you to override the default user info retrieval process.

```ts title="auth.ts"
import { betterAuth } from "better-auth";

export const auth = betterAuth({
  // Other configurations...
  socialProviders: {
    google: {
      clientId: "YOUR_GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID",
      clientSecret: "YOUR_GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET",
      getUserInfo: async (token) => {
        // Custom implementation to get user info
        const response = await fetch("https://www.googleapis.com/oauth2/v2/userinfo", {
          headers: {
            Authorization: `Bearer ${token.accessToken}`,
          },
        });
        const profile = await response.json();
        return {
          user: {
            id: profile.id,
            name: profile.name,
            email: profile.email,
            image: profile.picture,
            emailVerified: profile.verified_email,
          },
          data: profile,
        };
      },
    },
  },
});
```

### disableImplicitSignUp

Disables implicit sign up for new users. When set to true for the provider, sign-in needs to be called with `requestSignUp` as true to create new users.

```ts title="auth.ts"
import { betterAuth } from "better-auth";

export const auth = betterAuth({
  // Other configurations...
  socialProviders: {
    google: {
      clientId: "YOUR_GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID",
      clientSecret: "YOUR_GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET",
      disableImplicitSignUp: true,
    },
  },
});
```

### prompt

The prompt to use for the authorization code request. This controls the authentication flow behavior.

```ts title="auth.ts"
import { betterAuth } from "better-auth";

export const auth = betterAuth({
  // Other configurations...
  socialProviders: {
    google: {
      clientId: "YOUR_GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID",
      clientSecret: "YOUR_GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET",
      prompt: "select_account", // or "consent", "login", "none", "select_account+consent"
    },
  },
});
```

### responseMode

The response mode to use for the authorization code request. This determines how the authorization response is returned.

```ts title="auth.ts"
import { betterAuth } from "better-auth";

export const auth = betterAuth({
  // Other configurations...
  socialProviders: {
    google: {
      clientId: "YOUR_GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID",
      clientSecret: "YOUR_GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET",
      responseMode: "query", // or "form_post"
    },
  },
});
```

### disableDefaultScope

Removes the default scopes of the provider. By default, providers include certain scopes like `email` and `profile`. Set this to `true` to remove these default scopes and use only the scopes you specify.

```ts title="auth.ts"
import { betterAuth } from "better-auth";

export const auth = betterAuth({
  // Other configurations...
  socialProviders: {
    google: {
      clientId: "YOUR_GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID",
      clientSecret: "YOUR_GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET",
      disableDefaultScope: true,
      scope: ["https://www.googleapis.com/auth/userinfo.email"], // Only this scope will be used
    },
  },
});
```

### Other Provider Configurations

Each provider may have additional options, check the specific provider documentation for more details.

+## üéì Understanding the Issue
+
+### Why Redirect URI Must Match EXACTLY:
+OAuth 2.0 security requires that the redirect URI configured in the OAuth provider (Google) **exactly matches** what the auth server (Convex Better Auth) sends during the authorization request. Even small differences like:

+- `.cloud` vs `.site`
+- Trailing slash vs no trailing slash
+- Different subdomain
+
+...will cause the OAuth flow to fail with "Redirect URI mismatch" error.
+
+### Why Extension ID in trustedOrigins:
+Better Auth checks the `Origin` header of incoming requests. Chrome extensions send `Origin: chrome-extension://[EXTENSION_ID]`. If this ID isn't in the `trustedOrigins` array, Convex will block the request due to CORS policy, preventing session creation.

# integrations: Convex Integration

title: Convex Integration
description: Integrate Better Auth with Convex.
-----------------------------------------------

<Callout>
  This documentation comes from the [Convex documentation](https://convex-better-auth.netlify.app/),
  for more information, please refer to their documentation.
</Callout>

## Prerequisites

<Steps>
  <Step>
    ### Create a Convex project

    To use Convex + Better Auth, you'll first need a [Convex](https://www.convex.dev/) project.
    If you don't have one, run the following command to get started.

    <CodeBlockTabs defaultValue="npm">
      <CodeBlockTabsList>
        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="npm">
          npm
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>

        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="pnpm">
          pnpm
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>

        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="yarn">
          yarn
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>

        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="bun">
          bun
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>
      </CodeBlockTabsList>

      <CodeBlockTab value="npm">
        ```bash
        npm create convex@latest
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>

      <CodeBlockTab value="pnpm">
        ```bash
        pnpm create convex
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>

      <CodeBlockTab value="yarn">
        ```bash
        yarn create convex
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>

      <CodeBlockTab value="bun">
        ```bash
        bunx create-convex
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>
    </CodeBlockTabs>

    Check out the [Convex docs](https://docs.convex.dev/home) to learn more about Convex.
  </Step>

  <Step>
    ### Run `convex dev`

    Running the CLI during setup will initialize your Convex deployment
    if it doesn't already exist, and keeps generated types current through the process. Keep it running.

    <CodeBlockTabs defaultValue="npm">
      <CodeBlockTabsList>
        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="npm">
          npm
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>

        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="pnpm">
          pnpm
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>

        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="yarn">
          yarn
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>

        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="bun">
          bun
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>
      </CodeBlockTabsList>

      <CodeBlockTab value="npm">
        ```bash
        npx convex dev
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>

      <CodeBlockTab value="pnpm">
        ```bash
        pnpm dlx convex dev
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>

      <CodeBlockTab value="yarn">
        ```bash
        yarn dlx convex dev
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>

      <CodeBlockTab value="bun">
        ```bash
        bun x convex dev
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>
    </CodeBlockTabs>
  </Step>
</Steps>

## Installation of Convex + Better Auth

The following documentation assumes you're using Next.js.

If you're not using Next.js, please refer to the [installation guide by Convex](https://convex-better-auth.netlify.app/#select-your-framework).

<Callout>
  For a complete example, check out Convex + Better Auth example with Next.js in this [Github repository](https://github.com/get-convex/better-auth/tree/main/examples/next).
</Callout>

### Installation

<Steps>
  <Step>
    #### Install packages

    Install the component, a pinned version of Better Auth, and ensure the latest version of Convex.

    <Callout>
      This component requires Convex `1.25.0` or later.
    </Callout>

    <CodeBlockTabs defaultValue="npm">
      <CodeBlockTabsList>
        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="npm">
          npm
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>

        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="pnpm">
          pnpm
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>

        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="yarn">
          yarn
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>

        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="bun">
          bun
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>
      </CodeBlockTabsList>

      <CodeBlockTab value="npm">
        ```bash
        npm install better-auth@1.3.8 --save-exact
        npm install convex@latest @convex-dev/better-auth
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>

      <CodeBlockTab value="pnpm">
        ```bash
        pnpm add better-auth@1.3.8 --save-exact
        pnpm add convex@latest @convex-dev/better-auth
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>

      <CodeBlockTab value="yarn">
        ```bash
        yarn add better-auth@1.3.8 --exact
        yarn add convex@latest @convex-dev/better-auth
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>

      <CodeBlockTab value="bun">
        ```bash
        bun add better-auth@1.3.8 --exact
        bun add convex@latest @convex-dev/better-auth
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>
    </CodeBlockTabs>
  </Step>

  <Step>
    #### Register the component

    Register the Better Auth component in your Convex project.

    ```ts title="convex/convex.config.ts"
    import { defineApp } from "convex/server";
    import betterAuth from "@convex-dev/better-auth/convex.config";

    const app = defineApp();
    app.use(betterAuth);

    export default app;
    ```
  </Step>

  <Step>
    #### Add Convex auth config

    Add a `convex/auth.config.ts` file to configure Better Auth as an authentication provider.

    ```ts title="convex/auth.config.ts"
    export default {
        providers: [
            {
                domain: process.env.CONVEX_SITE_URL,
                applicationID: "convex",
            },
        ],
    };
    ```
  </Step>

  <Step>
    #### Set environment variables

    Generate a secret for encryption and generating hashes. Use the command below if you have openssl installed,
    or use the button to generate a random value instead. Or generate your own however you like.

    <CodeBlockTabs defaultValue="npm">
      <CodeBlockTabsList>
        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="npm">
          npm
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>

        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="pnpm">
          pnpm
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>

        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="yarn">
          yarn
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>

        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="bun">
          bun
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>
      </CodeBlockTabsList>

      <CodeBlockTab value="npm">
        ```bash
        npx convex env set BETTER_AUTH_SECRET=$(openssl rand -base64 32)
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>

      <CodeBlockTab value="pnpm">
        ```bash
        pnpm dlx convex env set BETTER_AUTH_SECRET=$(openssl rand -base64 32)
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>

      <CodeBlockTab value="yarn">
        ```bash
        yarn dlx convex env set BETTER_AUTH_SECRET=$(openssl rand -base64 32)
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>

      <CodeBlockTab value="bun">
        ```bash
        bun x convex env set BETTER_AUTH_SECRET=$(openssl rand -base64 32)
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>
    </CodeBlockTabs>

    Add your site URL to your Convex deployment.

    <CodeBlockTabs defaultValue="npm">
      <CodeBlockTabsList>
        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="npm">
          npm
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>

        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="pnpm">
          pnpm
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>

        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="yarn">
          yarn
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>

        <CodeBlockTabsTrigger value="bun">
          bun
        </CodeBlockTabsTrigger>
      </CodeBlockTabsList>

      <CodeBlockTab value="npm">
        ```bash
        npx convex env set SITE_URL http://localhost:3000
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>

      <CodeBlockTab value="pnpm">
        ```bash
        pnpm dlx convex env set SITE_URL http://localhost:3000
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>

      <CodeBlockTab value="yarn">
        ```bash
        yarn dlx convex env set SITE_URL http://localhost:3000
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>

      <CodeBlockTab value="bun">
        ```bash
        bun x convex env set SITE_URL http://localhost:3000
        ```
      </CodeBlockTab>
    </CodeBlockTabs>

    Add environment variables to the `.env.local` file created by `npx convex dev`.
    It will be picked up by your framework dev server.

    ```shell title=".env.local" tab="Cloud"
    # Deployment used by \`npx convex dev\`
    CONVEX_DEPLOYMENT=dev:adjective-animal-123 # team: team-name, project: project-name

    NEXT_PUBLIC_CONVEX_URL=https://adjective-animal-123.convex.cloud

    # Same as NEXT_PUBLIC_CONVEX_URL but ends in .site // [!code ++]
    NEXT_PUBLIC_CONVEX_SITE_URL=https://adjective-animal-123.convex.site # [!code ++]

    # Your local site URL // [!code ++]
    SITE_URL=http://localhost:3000 # [!code ++]
    ```

    ```shell title=".env.local" tab="Self hosted"
    # Deployment used by \`npx convex dev\`
    CONVEX_DEPLOYMENT=dev:adjective-animal-123 # team: team-name, project: project-name

    NEXT_PUBLIC_CONVEX_URL=http://127.0.0.1:3210

    # Will generally be one number higher than NEXT_PUBLIC_CONVEX_URL,
    # so if your convex url is :3212, your site url will be :3213
    NEXT_PUBLIC_CONVEX_SITE_URL=http://127.0.0.1:3211 # [!code ++]

    # Your local site URL // [!code ++]
    SITE_URL=http://localhost:3000 # [!code ++]
    ```
  </Step>

  <Step>
    ### Create a Better Auth instance

    Create a Better Auth instance and initialize the component.

    <Callout>Some TypeScript errors will show until you save the file.</Callout>

    ```ts title="convex/auth.ts"
    import { createClient, type GenericCtx } from "@convex-dev/better-auth";
    import { convex } from "@convex-dev/better-auth/plugins";
    import { components } from "./_generated/api";
    import { DataModel } from "./_generated/dataModel";
    import { query } from "./_generated/server";
    import { betterAuth } from "better-auth";

    const siteUrl = process.env.SITE_URL!;

    // The component client has methods needed for integrating Convex with Better Auth,
    // as well as helper methods for general use.
    export const authComponent = createClient<DataModel>(components.betterAuth);

    export const createAuth = (
        ctx: GenericCtx<DataModel>,
            { optionsOnly } = { optionsOnly: false },
        ) => {
          return betterAuth({
            // disable logging when createAuth is called just to generate options.
            // this is not required, but there's a lot of noise in logs without it.
            logger: {
                disabled: optionsOnly,
            },
            baseURL: siteUrl,
            database: authComponent.adapter(ctx),
            // Configure simple, non-verified email/password to get started
            emailAndPassword: {
                enabled: true,
                requireEmailVerification: false,
            },
            plugins: [
                // The Convex plugin is required for Convex compatibility
                convex(),
            ],
        });
    };

    // Example function for getting the current user
    // Feel free to edit, omit, etc.
    export const getCurrentUser = query({
        args: {},
        handler: async (ctx) => {
            return authComponent.getAuthUser(ctx);
        },
    });
    ```
  </Step>

  <Step>
    ### Create a Better Auth client instance

    Create a Better Auth client instance for interacting with the Better Auth server from your client.

    ```ts title="src/lib/auth-client.ts"
    import { createAuthClient } from "better-auth/react";
    import { convexClient } from "@convex-dev/better-auth/client/plugins";

    export const authClient = createAuthClient({
        plugins: [convexClient()],
    });
    ```
  </Step>

  <Step>
    ### Mount handlers

    Register Better Auth route handlers on your Convex deployment.

    ```ts title="convex/http.ts"
    import { httpRouter } from "convex/server";
    import { authComponent, createAuth } from "./auth";

    const http = httpRouter();

    authComponent.registerRoutes(http, createAuth);

    export default http;
    ```

    Set up route handlers to proxy auth requests from your framework server to your Convex deployment.

    ```ts title="app/api/auth/[...all]/route.ts"
    import { nextJsHandler } from "@convex-dev/better-auth/nextjs";

    export const { GET, POST } = nextJsHandler();
    ```
  </Step>

  <Step>
    ### Set up Convex client provider

    Wrap your app with the `ConvexBetterAuthProvider` component.

    ```ts title="app/ConvexClientProvider.tsx"
    "use client";

    import { ReactNode } from "react";
    import { ConvexReactClient } from "convex/react";
    import { authClient } from "@/lib/auth-client"; // [!code ++]
    import { ConvexBetterAuthProvider } from "@convex-dev/better-auth/react"; // [!code ++]

    const convex = new ConvexReactClient(process.env.NEXT_PUBLIC_CONVEX_URL!, {
      // Optionally pause queries until the user is authenticated // [!code ++]
      expectAuth: true, // [!code ++]
    });

    export function ConvexClientProvider({ children }: { children: ReactNode }) {
      return (
        <ConvexBetterAuthProvider client={convex} authClient={authClient}> // [!code ++]
          {children}
        </ConvexBetterAuthProvider> // [!code ++]
      );
    }
    ```
  </Step>
</Steps>

### You're done!

You're now ready to start using Better Auth with Convex.

## Usage

### Using Better Auth from the server

To use Better Auth's [server
methods](https://www.better-auth.com/docs/concepts/api) in server rendering,
server functions, or any other Next.js server code, use Convex functions
and call the function from your server code.

First, a token helper for calling Convex functions from your server code.

```ts title="src/lib/auth-server.ts"
import { createAuth } from "@/convex/auth";
import { getToken as getTokenNextjs } from "@convex-dev/better-auth/nextjs";

export const getToken = () => {
  return getTokenNextjs(createAuth);
};
```

Here's an example Convex function that uses Better Auth's server methods, and
a server action that calls the Convex function.

```ts title="convex/users.ts"
import { mutation } from "./_generated/server";
import { v } from "convex/values";
import { createAuth, authComponent } from "./auth";

export const updateUserPassword = mutation({
  args: {
    currentPassword: v.string(),
    newPassword: v.string(),
  },
  handler: async (ctx, args) => {
    await createAuth(ctx).api.changePassword({
      body: {
        currentPassword: args.currentPassword,
        newPassword: args.newPassword,
      },
      headers: await authComponent.getHeaders(ctx),
    });
  },
});
```

```ts title="app/actions.ts"
"use server";

import { fetchMutation } from "convex/nextjs";
import { api } from "../convex/_generated/api";
import { getToken } from "../lib/auth-server";

// Authenticated mutation via server function
export async function updatePassword({
  currentPassword,
  newPassword,
}: {
  currentPassword: string;
  newPassword: string;
}) {
  const token = await getToken();
  await fetchMutation(
    api.users.updatePassword,
    { currentPassword, newPassword },
    { token }
  );
}
```

<Callout>
  This documentation comes from the [Convex documentation](https://convex-better-auth.netlify.app/),
  for more information, please refer to their documentation.
</Callout>
